an inadvertent error in the execution date of the certifications filed as Exhibits 31.1, 31.2 and 32.1 thereto. This amendment is not intended to update any other information presented in the Annual Report as originally filed, which is reproduced
herein in its entirety for ease of reference. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:4px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P> <P STYLE="line-height:0px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;border-bottom:0.5pt solid #000000">&nbsp;</P> <P

<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Valuation and Qualifying Accounts</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">S-2</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:48px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In this report, &#147;Kraft,&#148; &#147;we,&#148; &#147;us&#148; and &#147;our&#148; refers to Kraft Foods Inc.
and subsidiaries, and &#147;Common Stock&#148; refers to Kraft&#146;s Class&nbsp;A common stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">1 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc66459_a"></A>PART&nbsp;I </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc66459_1"></A>Item&nbsp;1.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Business. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>General </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft was incorporated in 2000 in the Commonwealth of Virginia. We manufacture and market packaged foods and beverages worldwide in more than 150 countries. We have nine
brands with revenues exceeding $1 billion: <I>Kraft</I> cheeses, dinners and dressings; <I>Oscar Mayer</I> meats; <I>Philadelphia</I> cream cheese; <I>Maxwell House</I> coffee; <I>Nabisco</I> cookies and crackers and its <I>Oreo</I> brand;
<I>Jacobs</I> coffees, <I>Milka</I> chocolates and <I>LU</I> biscuits. We have more than 50 additional brands with revenues of at least $100 million. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Prior to June&nbsp;13, 2001, Kraft was a wholly-owned subsidiary of Altria Group,&nbsp;Inc. (&#147;Altria&#148;). On June&nbsp;13, 2001, we completed an initial public offering of 280,000,000 shares of our Common Stock at a price of $31.00
per share. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In the first quarter of 2007, Altria spun off its remaining interest (89.0%)&nbsp;in Kraft on a pro rata basis to Altria stockholders in a
tax-free transaction. Effective as of the close of business on March&nbsp;30, 2007, all Kraft shares owned by Altria were distributed to Altria&#146;s stockholders, and our separation from Altria was completed (the &#147;Distribution&#148;). Before
the Distribution, Altria converted all of its Class&nbsp;B shares of Kraft common stock into Class&nbsp;A shares of Kraft common stock. The Distribution ratio was calculated by dividing the number of shares of Kraft Common Stock held by Altria by
the number of Altria shares outstanding on the record date, March&nbsp;16, 2007. The distribution ratio was 0.692024 shares of Kraft Common Stock for every share of Altria common stock outstanding. Following the Distribution, we only have
Class&nbsp;A common stock outstanding. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Because Kraft is a holding company, our principal source of funds is dividends from our subsidiaries. Our principal
wholly-owned subsidiaries currently are not limited by long-term debt or other agreements in their ability to pay cash dividends or make other distributions with respect to their common stock. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Reportable Segments </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We manufacture and market packaged food
products, including snacks, beverages, cheese, convenient meals and various packaged grocery products. We manage and report operating results through two commercial units, Kraft North America and Kraft International. Kraft North America operates in
the U.S. and Canada, and we manage Kraft North America&#146;s operations by product category. We manage Kraft International&#146;s operations by geographic location. We have operations in more than 70 countries and sell our products in more than 150
countries. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Note 16 to our consolidated financial statements includes a breakout of net revenues and segment operating income by reportable segment for
each of the last three years. Management uses segment operating income to evaluate segment performance and allocate resources. Segment operating income excludes unallocated general corporate expenses and amortization of intangibles. Management
believes it is appropriate to disclose this measure to help investors analyze segment performance and trends. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The relative percentages of segment
operating income attributable to each reportable segment were: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="92%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="29%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="5%"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="4%"></TD>

<TD></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This segment was formerly known as Developing Markets, Oceania&nbsp;&amp; North Asia </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">2 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our brands span five consumer sectors: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Snacks</B> - primarily cookies, crackers, salted snacks and chocolate confectionery; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Beverages</B> - primarily coffee, aseptic juice drinks and powdered beverages; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Cheese</B> - primarily natural, process and cream cheeses; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Grocery</B> - primarily ready-to-eat cereals, enhancers and desserts; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Convenient Meals</B> - primarily frozen pizza, packaged dinners, lunch combinations and processed meats. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">4 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">


<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" ALIGN="center">

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="29%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="69%"></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cheese:</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Kraft, Velveeta,</I> and <I>Eden</I> process cheeses; <I>Kraft</I> and <I>Philadelphia</I> cream cheese; <I>Kraft</I> natural cheese; and <I>Cheez Whiz</I> process cheese
spread.</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Grocery:</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Royal</I> dry packaged desserts; <I>Post</I> ready-to-eat cereals; <I>Kraft</I> spoonable and pourable salad dressings; <I>Miracle Whip spoonable dressings</I>; <I>Jell-O</I> dessert
toppings; <I>Kraft</I> peanut butter; and <I>Vegemite</I> yeast spread.</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:2.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Convenient Meals:</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Kraft</I> macaroni&nbsp;&amp; cheese dinners.</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Note that foodservice products span all Kraft North America segments and sectors. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">In February 2008, we announced the implementation of our new operating structure. Our new structure reflects our strategy to <I>Rewire the Organization for Growth</I>. Within our new structure, business units now have full P&amp;L
accountability and are staffed accordingly. This also ensures that we are putting our resources closer to where decisions are made that affect our consumers. Our corporate and shared service functions are streamlining their organizations and
focusing them on core activities that can more efficiently support the goals of the business units. Our new operating structure will result in changes to the reportable business segments within our North America commercial unit, beginning in the
first quarter of 2008. These changes are: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cheese has been organized as a standalone operating segment in order to create a more self-contained and integrated business unit in support of faster growth.
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are also moving our macaroni&nbsp;&amp; cheese category as well as other dinner products from our Convenient Meals segment to our Grocery segment to take
advantage of operating synergies. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="5%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="2%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Canada and North America Foodservice will be structured as a standalone reportable segment. This change will allow us to deliver on the unique requirements of the
Canadian consumer and customer while maintaining strong North American linkages to innovation, new product development and new capabilities to drive our business. Furthermore, it will allow us to manage strategic customer decisions and continue to
capture cross-border sales and marketing synergies within our Foodservice operations. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As a result of implementing our new operating
structure, we will report the results of operations under this new structure beginning in the first quarter of 2008 and we will restate results from prior periods in a consistent manner. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Significant Acquisitions and Divestitures </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Danone Biscuit: </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;30, 2007, we acquired the global biscuit business of Groupe Danone S.A. (&#147;Danone Biscuit&#148;) for &#128;5.1&nbsp;billion (approximately $7.6
billion) in cash subject to purchase price adjustments. On October&nbsp;12, 2007, we entered into a 364-day bridge facility agreement, and at closing, we borrowed &#128;5.1 billion under that facility in order to finance the acquisition. The
acquisition included 32 manufacturing facilities and approximately 14,000 employees. Danone Biscuit generated global revenues of approximately $2.8 billion during 2007. Danone Biscuit will report results from operations on a one month lag; as such,
there was no impact on our operating results in 2007. On a proforma basis, Danone Biscuit&#146;s net earnings for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 would have been insignificant to Kraft. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Post Distribution: </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">On November&nbsp;15, 2007, we announced a
definitive agreement to merge our <I>Post</I> cereals business (&#147;Post Business&#148;) into Ralcorp Holdings, Inc. (&#147;Ralcorp&#148;) after a tax-free distribution to our shareholders (the &#147;Post Distribution&#148;). We have signed an
agreement with Ralcorp to execute the Post Distribution by means of a &#147;Reverse-Morris Trust&#148; transaction. This transaction is subject to customary closing conditions, including anti-trust approval, IRS tax-free ruling and Ralcorp
shareholder approvals. To date, the anti-trust approval has been obtained. We anticipate that this transaction will be completed in mid-2008. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Post
Business had net revenues of approximately $1.1 billion in 2007 and includes such cereals as <I>Honey Bunches of Oats</I>, <I>Pebbles</I>, <I>Shredded Wheat</I>, <I>Selects</I>, <I>Grape Nuts</I> and <I>Honeycomb</I>. The brands in this transaction
are distributed primarily in North America. In addition to the <I>Post</I> brands, the transaction includes four manufacturing facilities and certain manufacturing equipment. We anticipate that approximately 1,250 employees will join Ralcorp
following the consummation of the transaction. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our shareholders will receive at least 30.3&nbsp;million shares of Ralcorp stock after the Post
Distribution and the subsequent merger of the Post Business with Ralcorp. Based on market conditions prior to closing, we will determine whether the shares will be distributed in a spin-off or a split-off transaction. Either type of transaction is
expected to be tax-free to our U.S. shareholders. In a spin-off transaction, our shareholders would receive a pro rata number of Ralcorp shares. In a split-off transaction, our shareholders would have the option to exchange their Kraft shares and
receive Ralcorp shares at closing, resulting in a reduction </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">5 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">in the number of shares of our Common Stock outstanding. In addition, Kraft will receive approximately $960 million of cash-equivalent value, which will be
used to repay debt. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Customers </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our five largest
customers accounted for approximately 28% of our net revenues in 2007, 29% in 2006 and 26% in 2005. Our ten largest customers accounted for approximately 37% of our net revenues in 2007, 40% in 2006 and 37% in 2005. One of our customers, Wal-Mart
Stores,&nbsp;Inc., accounted for approximately 15% of our net revenues in 2007, 15% in 2006 and 14% in 2005. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Seasonality </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Demand for some of our products may be influenced by holidays, changes in seasons or other annual events. However, sales of our products are generally evenly balanced
throughout the year due to the offsetting nature of demands for our diversified product portfolio. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Competition </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We face competition in all aspects of our business. Competitors include large national and international companies and numerous local and regional companies. Some
competitors may have different profit objectives and some international competitors may be more or less susceptible to currency exchange rates. We also compete with generic products and retailer brands, wholesalers and cooperatives. We compete
primarily on the basis of product quality, brand recognition, brand loyalty, service, marketing, advertising and price. Moreover, improving our market position or introducing a new product requires substantial advertising and promotional
expenditures. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Distribution </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Kraft North
America&#146;s products are generally sold to supermarket chains, wholesalers, supercenters, club stores, mass merchandisers, distributors, convenience stores, gasoline stations, drug stores, value stores and other retail food outlets. In general,
the retail trade for food products is consolidating. Food products are distributed through distribution centers, satellite warehouses, company-operated and public cold-storage facilities, depots and other facilities. We currently distribute most
products in North America through warehouse delivery, but we deliver biscuits and frozen pizza through two direct-store delivery systems. We are in the process of combining the executional benefits of direct-store delivery with the economics of
warehouse delivery and plan to complete the full rollout of a wall-to-wall delivery system by mid-2008, where one sales representative covers an entire store. We support our selling efforts through three principal sets of activities: consumer
advertising in broadcast, print, outdoor and on-line media; consumer incentives such as coupons and contests; and trade promotions to support price features, displays and other merchandising of our products by our customers. Subsidiaries and
affiliates of Kraft International sell their food products primarily in the same manner and also engage the services of independent sales offices and agents. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Raw Materials </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are major purchasers of dairy, coffee, cocoa, wheat, corn products, soybean and vegetable oils, nuts, meat products, and
sugar and other sweeteners. We also use significant quantities of glass, plastic and cardboard to package our products, and natural gas for our factories and warehouses. We continuously monitor worldwide supply and cost trends of these commodities
so we can act quickly to obtain ingredients and packaging needed for production. We purchase a substantial portion of our dairy raw material requirements, including milk and cheese, from independent third parties such as agricultural cooperatives
and independent processors. The prices for milk and other dairy product purchases are substantially influenced by market supply and demand, as well as by government programs. Dairy commodity costs on average were $750 million higher in 2007 than in
2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The most significant cost item in coffee products is green coffee beans, which are purchased on world markets. Green coffee bean prices are affected
by the quality and availability of supply, trade agreements among producing and consuming nations, the unilateral policies of the producing nations, changes in the value of the U.S. dollar in relation to certain other currencies and consumer demand
for coffee products. In 2007, coffee bean costs on average were higher than in 2006. A significant cost item in chocolate confectionery products is cocoa, which is purchased on world markets, and the price of which is affected by the quality and
availability of supply and changes in the value of the British pound sterling and the U.S. dollar relative to certain other currencies. In 2007, cocoa bean and cocoa butter costs on average were higher than in 2006. Significant cost items in our
</FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">6 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">biscuit, cereal, and grocery products are grains or wheat, corn, and soybean oil. Grain costs have experienced significant cost increases as a result of
burgeoning global demand for food, livestock feed and biofuels such as ethanol and biodiesel. In 2007, grain costs on average were higher than in 2006. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">During 2007, our aggregate commodity costs rose significantly as a result of higher dairy, coffee, cocoa, wheat, meat products, soybean oil and packaging costs, partially offset by lower nut costs. For 2007, our commodity costs were
approximately $1,250&nbsp;million higher than 2006, following an increase of approximately $275&nbsp;million for 2006 compared with 2005. We expect the higher cost environment to continue, particularly for dairy, grains, energy and packaging.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The prices paid for raw materials and agricultural materials used in our products generally reflect external factors such as weather conditions, commodity
market fluctuations, currency fluctuations and the effects of governmental agricultural programs. Although the prices of the principal raw materials can be expected to fluctuate as a result of these factors, we believe there will be an adequate
supply of the raw materials we use and that they are generally available from numerous sources. We use hedging techniques to limit the impact of price fluctuations in our principal raw materials. However, we do not fully hedge against changes in
commodity prices and these strategies may not protect us from increases in specific raw material costs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Intellectual Property </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We consider our trademarks, in the aggregate, to be&nbsp;material&nbsp;to our business. We protect our trademarks by registration or otherwise in the U.S.
and&nbsp;in&nbsp;other markets where we sell our products.&nbsp;Trademark protection continues in some countries for as long as the mark is used and, in other countries, for as long as it is registered. Registrations generally are for fixed, but
renewable, terms. From time to time, we&nbsp;grant&nbsp;third parties licenses to use one or more of&nbsp;our trademarks in particular locations.&nbsp;Similarly,&nbsp;we sell some of&nbsp;our products under brands&nbsp;we license&nbsp;and&nbsp;those
licenses are generally renewable at&nbsp;our discretion. These licensed brands include, among others: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Starbucks</I> bagged coffee, <I>Seattle&#146;s Best</I> coffee, and <I>Torrefazione Italia</I> coffee for sale in U.S. grocery stores and other distribution
channels; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>South Beach Living </I>pizzas, meals, breakfast wraps, lunch wrap kits, crackers, cookies, snack bars, cereals and dressings for sale in grocery stores in the
U.S. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Additionally,&nbsp;we own&nbsp;numerous patents worldwide.&nbsp;While our patent portfolio is material to&nbsp;our
business,&nbsp;the loss of&nbsp;one patent or&nbsp;a&nbsp;group of related patents&nbsp;would not have a material adverse effect on our business.&nbsp;We have either been issued patents or have patent applications pending that relate to a number of
current and potential products, including products licensed to others. Patents, issued or applied for, cover inventions ranging from basic&nbsp;packaging techniques to processes relating to specific products and to the products themselves. Our
issued patents extend for varying periods according to the date of patent application filing or grant and the legal term of patents in the various countries where patent protection is obtained. The actual protection afforded by a patent, which can
vary from country to country, depends upon the type of patent, the scope of its coverage as determined by the patent office or courts in the country, and the availability of legal remedies in the country. We consider that in the aggregate our patent
applications, patents and licenses under patents owned by third parties are of material importance to our operations. We are currently involved in a number of legal proceedings relating to the scope of protection and validity of our patents and
those of others. These proceedings may result in a significant commitment of our resources in the future and, depending on their outcome, may adversely affect the validity and scope of certain of our patent or other proprietary rights. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We also have proprietary trade secrets, technology, know-how processes and&nbsp;related&nbsp;intellectual property rights that are not registered. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Research and Development </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We pursue four objectives in research and
development: product safety and quality; growth through new products; superior consumer satisfaction; and reduced costs. We have more than 2,100 food scientists, chemists and engineers working primarily in </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">7 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">six key technology centers: East Hanover, New Jersey; Glenview, Illinois; Tarrytown, New York; Banbury, United Kingdom; Paris, France; and Munich, Germany.
These technology centers are equipped with pilot plants and state-of-the-art instruments. Research and development expense was $447 million in 2007, $419&nbsp;million in 2006 and $385&nbsp;million in 2005. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Regulation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our U.S. food products and packaging materials
are&nbsp;regulated by the&nbsp;Food and Drug Administration or, for products containing meat and poultry, the Food Safety and Inspection Service of the U.S. Department of Agriculture.&nbsp;These agencies enact and enforce regulations relating to the
manufacturing, distribution and labeling of food products. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, various states regulate&nbsp;our U.S. operations by licensing plants, enforcing
federal and state standards for selected food products, grading food products, inspecting plants and warehouses, regulating&nbsp;trade practices&nbsp;related to the sale of dairy products and imposing their own labeling requirements on food
products. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Many of the food commodities&nbsp;we use in&nbsp;our U.S. operations&nbsp;are subject to governmental agricultural programs. These programs have
substantial effects on prices and supplies and are subject to Congressional and administrative review. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">All of&nbsp;our non-U.S.-based&nbsp;operations are
subject to local and national regulations&nbsp;some of which are similar to those applicable to&nbsp;our U.S. operations.&nbsp;For example, in the EU,&nbsp;requirements apply to labeling, packaging, food content, pricing, marketing and advertising
and related areas. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Environmental Regulation </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are
subject to various federal, state, local and foreign laws and regulations relating to the protection of the environment. We accrue for environmental remediation obligations on an undiscounted basis when amounts are probable and can be reasonably
estimated. The accruals are adjusted as new information develops or circumstances change. Recoveries of environmental remediation costs from third parties are recorded as assets when their receipt is deemed probable. In the U.S., the laws and
regulations include the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and Superfund, which imposes joint and severable liability on each responsible party. As of December&nbsp;31, 2007,&nbsp;our subsidiaries were
involved in 70 active Superfund and other similar actions in the U.S. related to current operations and certain former or divested operations for which we retain liability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Outside the U.S., we are subject to applicable multi-national, national and local environmental laws and regulations in the host countries in which we do business. We have specific programs across our international
business units designed to meet applicable environmental compliance requirements. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Based on information currently available, we believe that the ultimate
resolution of existing environmental remediation actions and our compliance in general with environmental laws and regulations will not have a material effect on our financial results. However, we cannot quantify with certainty the potential impact
of future compliance efforts and environmental remediation actions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Employees </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At December&nbsp;31, 2007, we employed approximately 103,000 people worldwide. Labor unions represent approximately 30% of our 41,000 employees in the U.S. Most of the unionized workers at our domestic locations are
represented under contracts with the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union; the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union; and the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. These contracts expire at
various times throughout the next several years. Outside the U.S., labor unions or workers&#146; councils represent approximately 55% of our 62,000 employees. Our business units are subject to various laws and regulations relating to their
relationships with their employees. These laws and regulations are specific to the location of each enterprise. In addition, in accordance with EU requirements, we have established European Works Councils composed of management and elected members
of our workforce. We believe that our relationships with employees and their representative organizations are good. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In January 2004, we announced a
three-year restructuring program (the &#147;Restructuring Program&#148;) and, in January 2006, extended it through 2008. In connection with our severance initiatives, we have eliminated approximately 11,000 positions as of December&nbsp;31, 2007; at
that time we had announced the elimination of an additional 400 positions. Upon completion of the Restructuring Program, we expect to have eliminated approximately 13,500 positions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">8 </FONT></P>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Jean E. Spence</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">50</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President, Global Technology and Quality</FONT></P></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Mary Beth West</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">45</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Executive Vice President&nbsp;and Chief Marketing Officer</FONT></P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld </I>was appointed as Chief Executive Officer of Kraft in June&nbsp;2006 and assumed the
additional role of Chairman in March 2007. Prior to that, she had been Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Frito-Lay, a division of PepsiCo. Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld had been employed continuously by Kraft in various capacities from 1981 until 2003.
Ms.&nbsp;Rosenfeld is also a member of the Cornell University Board of Trustees. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Brearton </I>was appointed to his current position effective
January&nbsp;1, 2008. Prior to that, he served as Executive Vice&nbsp;President, Global Business Services and Strategy, as Senior Vice President of Business Process Simplification and as Corporate Controller for Kraft Foods Inc. He previously served
as a Senior Vice President, Finance for Kraft. Mr.&nbsp;Brearton first joined Kraft in 1984. Mr.&nbsp;Brearton is also on the Board of Directors for America&#146;s Second Harvest. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Firestone</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President, Corporate and Legal Affairs and General Counsel in January 2006. He previously served as Kraft&#146;s Executive Vice President, General Counsel and
Corporate Secretary. Prior to joining Kraft in 2003, Mr.&nbsp;Firestone served as Senior Vice President and General Counsel of Philip Morris International. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Khosla</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President and President, Kraft International in January 2007. Before joining Kraft, he served as the Managing Director of the consumer and foodservice business for the New Zealand-based
Fonterra Co-operative Group. Previously Mr.&nbsp;Khosla spent 27 years with Unilever in India, London and Europe. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;May </I>was appointed as
Executive Vice President, Global Human Resources in October 2005. Prior to joining Kraft, she had been Corporate Vice President, Human Resources for Baxter International Inc. Ms.&nbsp;May serves on the Board of Directors of MB Financial Inc.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;McLevish </I>was appointed as Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in October 2007. Prior to that, he had been the Senior Vice
President and Chief Financial Officer at Ingersoll-Rand Company Limited. Mr.&nbsp;McLevish serves on the Board of Directors of Kennametal Inc. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Mr.&nbsp;Searer</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President and President, Kraft North America in September 2006.&nbsp;Previously, Mr.&nbsp;Searer served as the Group Vice President and President, North America Convenient Meals Sector.
Mr.&nbsp;Searer joined Kraft in 1981. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;Spence</I> was appointed as Executive Vice President, Global Technology and Quality in January 2004.
Prior to her current position, Ms.&nbsp;Spence served as the Senior Vice President, Research and Development, Kraft Foods North America. She joined Kraft in 1981. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>Ms.&nbsp;West </I>was appointed as Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer in October 2007. Previously, she served as a Group Vice President for Kraft and President of the North America Beverages Sector. Ms.&nbsp;West joined
Kraft in 1986. Ms.&nbsp;West currently serves on Board of Directors for J.C. Penney Co., Inc. and is a member of the Executive Leadership Council. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><I>James P. Dollive</I>, 56, was appointed Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer in&nbsp;2006.&nbsp;In&nbsp;2001, he was named&nbsp;as&nbsp;Senior&nbsp;Vice President and Chief Financial Officer and&nbsp;prior to that he
held&nbsp;various positions with increasing responsibility&nbsp;within Kraft.&nbsp;Mr.&nbsp;Dollive&nbsp;joined&nbsp;Kraft in 1978 and&nbsp;will retire from Kraft effective February&nbsp;29, 2008. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">9 </FONT></P>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Franz - Josef H. Vogelsang</I>, 57, was appointed as Executive Vice President, Global Supply Chain in January 2004.
Prior to that role, he served as Senior Vice President, Operations, Procurement and Supply Chain for Kraft Foods International since 1998. Mr.&nbsp;Vogelsang retired from Kraft on January&nbsp;1, 2008.</FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We adopted The Kraft Foods Code of Conduct for Compliance and Integrity, which qualifies as a code of ethics under Item&nbsp;406 of Regulation&nbsp;S-K. The code applies
to all of our employees, including our principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller, and persons performing similar functions. Our code of ethics is available free of charge on our website at
<U>http://www.kraft.com/assets/pdf/KraftFoods_CodeofConduct.pdf</U> and will be provided free of charge to any stockholder submitting a written request to: Corporate Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. We will
disclose any waiver we grant to our principal executive officer, principal financial officer, principal accounting officer or controller under our code of ethics, or certain amendments to the code of ethics, on our website at <U>www.kraft.com</U>.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, we adopted Corporate Governance Guidelines, charters for each of the Board&#146;s four standing committees and the Code of Business Conduct
and Ethics for Directors. All of these materials are available on our website at <U>www.kraft.com</U> and will be provided free of charge to any stockholder requesting a copy by writing to: Corporate Secretary, Kraft Foods&nbsp;Inc., Three Lakes
Drive, Northfield, IL 60093. Certain of these materials may also be found in the proxy statement relating to our 2008 Annual Meeting of Shareholders. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Available Information </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our Internet address is <U>www.kraft.com</U>. Our Annual Reports on Form 10-K, Quarterly Reports on Form&nbsp;10-Q,
Current Reports on Form&nbsp;8-K and amendments to those reports filed or furnished pursuant to Section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, are available free of charge as soon as possible after we electronically
file them with, or furnish them to, the SEC. You can access our filings with the SEC by visiting <U>http://www.kraft.com/Investor/sec-filings-annual-report/</U>. The information on our website is not, and shall not be deemed to be, a part of this
Annual Report on Form 10-K or incorporated into any other filings we make with the SEC. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">You can also read and copy any document that we file, including
this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K, at the SEC&#146;s Public Reference Room at 100&nbsp;F&nbsp;Street, N.E., Washington, D.C. 20549. Call the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330 for information on the operation of the Public Reference Room. In addition, the SEC
maintains an Internet site at <U>www.sec.gov</U> that contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file electronically with the SEC. You can electronically access our SEC filings there. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Forward-Looking Statements </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This report contains forward-looking
statements regarding our expectation that there will be an adequate supply of the raw materials we use and that they are generally available from numerous sources; that our relationships with our employees and their representative organizations are
good; with regard to our intent to merge our <I>Post </I>cereals business with Ralcorp, the closing date and that closing is subject to customary closing conditions, the number of employees we anticipate will join Ralcorp, the amount of Ralcorp
stock our shareholders will own, that the transaction is expected to be tax-free to our U.S. shareholders, the effects depending on whether we determine to do a spin-off or a split-off and the amount of cash we will receive; with regard to the
Danone global biscuit business that we plan to build profitable scale by expanding distribution reach in countries with rapidly growing demand; our plan to contain administrative overhead while investing in quality, R&amp;D, marketing, sales and
other capabilities that support growth; the amount we will spend on quality upgrades in 2008; with regard to our Restructuring Program, our pre-tax charges, the number of facilities we intend to close and the number of positions we will eliminate,
the use of cash to pay approximately $1.7 billion of the charges and the amount of cumulative and annualized savings; with regard to implementing our new operating structure, the intent to simplify, streamline and increase accountability to generate
reliable growth for Kraft and the number of positions we are eliminating; the number of positions we will eliminate in connection with severance initiatives; our belief that the ultimate resolution of existing environmental remediation actions and
our compliance with environmental laws and regulations will not have a material effect on our financial results; that the assumptions we use in recording our pension and postretirement plan obligations are reasonable; our health care cost trend rate
assumption; the date we intend to adopt the measurement provisions of SFAS No. 158 and that it will not have a significant impact; our anticipated decrease in 2008 pre-tax U.S. and non-U.S. pension and postretirement expense and that our assumptions
will not change further; our belief regarding our liquidity; our growth strategy regarding acquisitions and divestitures; our expectation for, and how we intend to fund, 2008 capital expenditures; our intent to repay borrowings under </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">10 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">the&nbsp;Danone Biscuit facility from the proceeds of the issuance of investment grade bonds or other securities; our expectation to continue to meet
financial covenants under our revolving credit facility;&nbsp;the amount of our expected payment&nbsp;for tax liabilities; our expectation to complete the current authorization under our share repurchase program before the authorization expires in
March 2009;&nbsp;and&nbsp;our 2008 Outlook, specifically diluted EPS, costs, savings and spending related to our Restructuring Program; and our 2008 effective tax rate. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">These forward-looking statements involve risks and uncertainties, and the cautionary statements&nbsp;contained in the &#147;Risk Factors&#148; found in&nbsp;this Annual Report on Form 10-K&nbsp;identify important
factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from those predicted in any such forward-looking statements. Such factors,&nbsp;include, but are not limited to,&nbsp;continued higher input&nbsp;costs, pricing actions,&nbsp;increased
competition, our ability to differentiate our products from private label products, increased costs of sales, our ability to realize the expected cost savings&nbsp;and spending from our planned Restructuring Program,&nbsp;difficulty in obtaining
materials from our suppliers, the ability to supply our products and meet demand for our products, our indebtedness and our ability to pay our indebtedness, unexpected safety or manufacturing issues, FDA or other regulatory actions or delays,
unanticipated expenses such as litigation or legal settlement expenses, our inability to successfully integrate the Danone Biscuit business, our failure to consummate the <I>Post</I> merger, a shift in&nbsp;our product mix to lower margin offerings,
risks from operating internationally,&nbsp;our ability to protect our intellectual and other proprietary rights, our ability to retain key employees and tax law changes. We disclaim and do not undertake any obligation to update or revise any
forward-looking statement in this Form 10-K. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc66459_2"></A>Item&nbsp;1A.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Risk Factors. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>You should read the following risk factors
carefully in connection with evaluating our business and the forward-looking information contained in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. Any of the following risks could materially adversely affect our business, operating results, financial
condition and the actual outcome of matters as to which forward-looking statements are made in this Annual Report on Form&nbsp;10-K. While we believe we have identified and discussed below the key risk factors affecting our business, there may be
additional risks and uncertainties that are not presently known or that are not currently believed to be significant that may adversely affect our business, performance or financial condition in the future. </I></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>We operate in a highly competitive industry, which may affect&nbsp;our profitability. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The food industry is intensely competitive. We compete based on price, product innovation, product quality, brand recognition and loyalty, effectiveness of marketing, promotional activity and the ability to identify
and satisfy consumer preferences. From time to time,&nbsp;we may need to reduce&nbsp;our prices&nbsp;in response to&nbsp;competitive and customer pressures and to maintain&nbsp;our market share.&nbsp;Competition and customer pressures, however, also
may restrict&nbsp;our ability to increase prices in response to commodity and other input cost increases.&nbsp;Our results of operations will suffer if profit margins decrease, as a result of either a reduction in prices or increased input costs,
and&nbsp;if we are unable to increase sales volumes to offset those profit margin decreases. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We may also need to increase&nbsp;spending on marketing,
advertising and new product innovation to protect existing market share or capture increased market share. The success of&nbsp;our investments is&nbsp;subject to risks, including uncertainties about trade and consumer acceptance. As a
result,&nbsp;our increased expenditures may not maintain or enhance market share and could result in lower profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Our brand image may be
challenged to compete against lower-priced private label items, particularly in times of economic downturns. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Retailers are increasingly offering
private label products that compete with&nbsp;our products.&nbsp;Consumers&#146;&nbsp;willingness to purchase&nbsp;our products will depend upon&nbsp;our ability to offer products&nbsp;that appeal to consumers at the right price.&nbsp;It is also
important that our products are&nbsp;perceived to be of a higher quality than less expensive alternatives. If the difference in quality between our products and&nbsp;those of store brands narrows, or&nbsp;if such difference in quality is perceived
to have narrowed,&nbsp;then consumers may not&nbsp;buy&nbsp;our products. Furthermore,&nbsp;during periods of economic uncertainty, consumers tend to purchase more private label or other economy brands, which could&nbsp;reduce sales volumes of
our&nbsp;higher margin products or&nbsp;there could be a shift in our&nbsp;product mix to&nbsp;our lower margin offerings.&nbsp;If we are not able to maintain or improve&nbsp;our brand image, it could&nbsp;have a material affect on our market share
and&nbsp;our profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">11 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Consolidation of retail customers&nbsp;may affect our operating margins and profitability. In addition, the loss of a
significant&nbsp;customer could significantly affect our results of operations. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Retail customers, such as supermarkets, warehouse clubs and food
distributors,&nbsp;continue to consolidate in&nbsp;the U.S., the EU and&nbsp;our other major markets. These consolidations have produced large, sophisticated customers with increased buying power.&nbsp;These larger retailers are capable of operating
with reduced inventories,&nbsp;they can resist price increases,&nbsp;and they demand lower pricing, increased promotional programs and specifically tailored products.&nbsp;They also may use shelf space currently used for&nbsp;our products for their
own private label products.&nbsp;If we fail to respond to these trends, our volume growth could slow or we may need to lower our prices or increase our investments in marketing, any of which could adversely affect our profitability. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Our largest customer, Wal-Mart Stores, Inc., accounted for approximately 15% of our net revenues during 2007.&nbsp;During 2007, our five largest customers&nbsp;accounted
for approximately 28% of our net revenues.&nbsp;The loss of any one of our top customers could have a material adverse affect on our sales.</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Continuing
increases in commodity&nbsp;costs may affect our profitability. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We are a major purchaser of&nbsp;commodities including, dairy, coffee, cocoa, wheat,
corn products, soybean and vegetable oils, nuts, meat products, and sugar and other sweeteners. We also use significant quantities of glass, plastic and cardboard to package our products, and natural gas for our factories and warehouses.&nbsp;Price
volatility for commodities&nbsp;we purchase has increased due to conditions outside of&nbsp;our control, including fluctuations in commodities markets, currency fluctuations and changes in governmental agricultural programs. If&nbsp;we are unable to
increase our prices to offset increased commodity costs or achieve cost efficiencies in manufacturing and distribution, our&nbsp;profitability could suffer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2"><B>Our product sales depend on our ability to predict, identify and interpret changes in consumer preferences and develop&nbsp;and offer new products rapidly enough to meet those changes. </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Consumer preferences for food products&nbsp;change continually. For example, recently, consumers have been increasingly focused on health and wellness with respect to
the food products they buy. As a result,&nbsp;over the last several years our products have been subject to scrutiny relating to genetically modified organisms and the health implications of obesity and trans-fatty acids.&nbsp;Our success depends
on&nbsp;our ability to predict, identify and interpret the tastes and dietary habits of consumers and to offer products that appeal to those preferences.&nbsp;We have been and will continue to be&nbsp;affected by publicity concerning the health
implications of&nbsp;our products,&nbsp;some of which could negatively influence consumer perception and acceptance of&nbsp;our products and marketing programs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Furthermore, if&nbsp;we do not succeed in offering products that&nbsp;appeal to consumers, our sales and market share will decrease,&nbsp;and our profitability will suffer. We must be able to distinguish among short-term fads, mid-term
trends and long-term changes in consumer preferences. If&nbsp;we are unable to accurately predict which shifts in consumer preferences will be long-term, or&nbsp;if we fail to introduce new and improved products to satisfy those
preferences,&nbsp;our sales will decline. In addition,&nbsp;because of our varied consumer base, we must offer a sufficient array of products to satisfy the broad spectrum of consumer preferences.&nbsp;If we fail to successfully innovate products
across a multitude of product categories or if we do not rapidly develop products in faster growing and more profitable categories,&nbsp;demand for our products will decrease and our profitability could suffer. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Our international operations are subject to additional risks. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">Approximately 42% of our 2007 sales and approximately 39% of our 2006 sales were generated in foreign countries.&nbsp;Our international operations are subject to inherent risks, including fluctuations in currency values, unpredictability of
foreign currency exchange controls, discriminatory fiscal policies, unexpected changes in&nbsp;local regulations and laws in foreign countries and the uncertainty of enforcement of remedies in&nbsp;foreign jurisdictions.&nbsp;In addition,
international sales are subject to risks related to imposition of tariffs, quotas, trade barriers and other similar restrictions.&nbsp;Moreover, economic changes, terrorist activity, political unrest and other economic or political uncertainties may
interrupt or otherwise negatively affect our business. All of these risks could result in increased costs or decreased revenues, either of which could adversely affect our&nbsp;profitability. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>We may not be able to successfully consummate proposed acquisitions or divestitures or successfully integrate acquired businesses. </B></FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">From time to time,&nbsp;we evaluate acquisition candidates&nbsp;that would strategically fit&nbsp;our business objectives. If&nbsp;we are&nbsp;unable to complete,
successfully integrate and develop these acquisition candidates&nbsp;to realize revenue&nbsp;growth and cost savings,&nbsp;our </FONT>
</P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">12 </FONT></P>


<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" COLOR="#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">
<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">financial results could be adversely affected. In addition, from time to time,&nbsp;we divest businesses that&nbsp;do not meet
our&nbsp;strategic&nbsp;objectives, or do not meet&nbsp;our growth or profitability targets.&nbsp;Our&nbsp;profitability may be&nbsp;affected by either gains or losses on the sales of, or lost operating income from those businesses.&nbsp;Also,
we&nbsp;may not be able to complete desired or proposed divestitures on&nbsp;terms favorable to us.&nbsp;Moreover, we may&nbsp;incur asset impairment charges related to acquisitions or divestitures which may reduce&nbsp;our
profitability.&nbsp;Finally, our acquisition or divestiture activities may&nbsp;present financial, managerial and operational risks, including diversion of management attention from existing core businesses, integrating or separating personnel and
financial and other systems, adverse effects on existing business relationships with suppliers and customers, inaccurate estimates of fair value made in the accounting for acquisitions and amortization of acquired intangible assets which would
reduce future reported earnings, potential loss of customers or key employees of acquired businesses, and indemnities and potential disputes with the buyers or sellers.&nbsp;Any of these activities could affect our product sales, financial
conditions and results of operations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Product recalls, injuries caused by products or other legal claims could affect our reputation and profitability.
</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Selling products for human consumption involves inherent legal risks.&nbsp;We could be required to recall products due to product contamination,
spoilage or other adulteration, product misbranding or product tampering.&nbsp;We may also suffer losses if our&nbsp;products or operations violate applicable laws or regulations, or&nbsp;if our products cause injury, illness or death. In
addition,&nbsp;our advertising could be the target of claims of false or deceptive advertising.&nbsp;A significant product liability or other legal judgment against&nbsp;us, or a widespread product recall may&nbsp;adversely affect our
profitability.&nbsp;Moreover, even if a product liability or consumer fraud claim is unsuccessful, has no merit or is not pursued, the negative publicity surrounding&nbsp;assertions&nbsp;against our products or processes could adversely affect
our&nbsp;reputation and brand image. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>We operate in a highly regulated environment. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Food production and marketing are highly regulated by a variety of federal, state, local and foreign agencies. New regulations and changes to existing regulations are issued regularly. Increased governmental
regulation of the food industry, such as proposed requirements designed to enhance food safety or to regulate imported ingredients, could&nbsp;increase our costs and adversely affect&nbsp;our profitability. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Changes in our credit ratings could increase our financing costs. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">We maintain revolving credit facilities that historically have been used to support the issuance of commercial paper. A downgrade in our credit ratings, particularly our short-term debt rating, would likely reduce the amount of commercial
paper we could issue or it could&nbsp;raise our&nbsp;borrowing costs, or both. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Volatility in the equity markets or interest rates could substantially
increase our pension costs. </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the end of 2007, the projected benefit obligation&nbsp;of our defined benefit pension plans was $10.2&nbsp;billion
and&nbsp;assets were $11.0&nbsp;billion. The difference between plan obligations and assets, or the funded status of the plans,&nbsp;significantly affects the net periodic benefit costs of&nbsp;our pension plans and the ongoing funding requirements
of those plans. Among other factors, changes in interest rates, mortality rates, early retirement rates, investment returns and the market value of plan assets can (i)&nbsp;affect the level of plan funding; (ii)&nbsp;cause volatility in the net
periodic pension cost; and (iii)&nbsp;increase&nbsp;our future funding requirements. In addition,&nbsp;if we divest certain businesses, we may be required to increase future&nbsp;contributions to the benefit plans and the related net periodic
pension cost could increase. A significant increase in&nbsp;our funding requirements could have a negative impact on&nbsp;our results of operations and profitability. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc66459_3"></A>Item&nbsp;1B.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Unresolved Staff Comments. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have received no written comments
regarding our quarterly, annual or current reports from the staff of the SEC that remain unresolved. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">13 </FONT></P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Properties. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have 187 manufacturing and processing facilities
worldwide. In North America, we have 64 facilities, and outside of North America, we have 123 facilities located in 44 countries. These manufacturing and processing facilities are located throughout the following territories: </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We own 181 and lease six of these manufacturing and processing facilities. We maintain all of our plants and
properties in good condition, and we believe they are suitable and adequate for our present needs. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">We have publicly announced, but not yet completed the
sale or closure of five facilities in the U.S., three facilities in Canada, six facilities in Europe, one facility in Asia Pacific and two facilities in Latin America. The numbers above include these facilities. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As of December&nbsp;31, 2007, our distribution facilities consisted of 313 distribution centers and depots worldwide. In North America, we had 302 distribution centers
and depots, more than 75% of which support our direct-store-delivery systems. Outside North America, we had eleven distribution centers in seven countries. We own 39 of these distribution centers and three of these depots, and we lease 128 of these
distribution centers and 143 of these depots. We believe that all of these facilities are in good condition and have sufficient capacity to meet our distribution needs in the near future. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In January&nbsp;2004, we announced a three-year Restructuring Program and in January&nbsp;2006, extended it through 2008. As part of the Restructuring Program, we
anticipate closing up to 35 facilities. We announced the closure of three plants during 2007; we have now announced the closure of 30 facilities since the program began in 2004. </FONT></P> <P
STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc66459_5"></A>Item&nbsp;3.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Legal Proceedings. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:3px;line-Height:95%; vertical-align:top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman"
SIZE="2">On August&nbsp;27, 2007, The Proctor&nbsp;&amp; Gamble Company (&#147;P&amp;G&#148;) filed suit in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California against our wholly-owned subsidiary, Kraft Foods Global, Inc.
(&#147;KFGI&#148;), for patent infringement.&nbsp;P&amp;G alleges that&nbsp;the plastic packaging for&nbsp;our Maxwell House<FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP>&reg;</SUP></FONT> brand&nbsp;coffee infringes their U.S. Patent Number
7,169,418,&nbsp;entitled &#147;Packaging System to Provide Fresh Packed Coffee&#148; (&#147;P&amp;G Patent&#148;).&nbsp;P&amp;G seeks, among other things, preliminary and permanent injunctions enjoining our use of the alleged infringing plastic
packaging, and unspecified damages.&nbsp;The&nbsp;P&amp;G Patent&nbsp;is, at the same time,&nbsp;the subject of a pending&nbsp;<I>inter partes </I>reexamination proceeding before the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, which could either invalidate,
or validate, the patent, in its entirety or in part.&nbsp;For this reason, KFGI filed a Motion to Stay&nbsp;the patent infringement suit on grounds that the outcome of the <I>inter partes</I> reexamination could dispose of all or some of the
asserted claims. On October&nbsp;11, 2007, the Court granted&nbsp;KFGI&#146;s Motion to Stay.&nbsp;P&amp;G filed an appeal&nbsp;of the stay in the&nbsp;Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on November&nbsp;9, 2007, and KFGI then filed a motion
to dismiss P&amp;G&#146;s appeal on December&nbsp;17, 2007. A decision on the motion is pending at this time.&nbsp;No further rulings are expected in this patent infringement suit&nbsp;pending the outcome of the <I>inter partes</I> reexamination.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:24px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="10%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>
<A NAME="toc66459_6"></A>Item&nbsp;4.</B></FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders. </B></FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">No matters
were submitted to a vote of security holders during the fourth quarter of 2007. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="6%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Immediately following the Distribution, we announced a new $5.0 billion, two-year share repurchase program. We are not obligated to acquire any amount of our Common Stock and may
suspend the program at our discretion. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">

</FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT FACE="Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The principal stock exchange on which our Common Stock is listed is the NYSE. At January&nbsp;31, 2008, there were approximately 87,000
holders of record of our Common Stock. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
